On 2008-06-20, at 08:59 , milesy1981 wrote:
> Good Afternoon,
>
> I am trying to implement a better JUnit strategy here, and I was
> wondering if anyone has any tried and test ways of seperating out
> their different classes of testing. The line here is very fuzzy
> between what is an actual unit test and what is an integration test
> and I am trying to make that much more clearer.
>
> I want to have a bunch of test cases which purely test classes in
> isolation and test that their behaivour is as expected from an API
> standpoint, but I also want another set of tests which will test the
> actual functional and integration of things like making sure the
> integration with Spring and Hibernate is actually working and as I
> expect.
>
> Has anyone done this kind of seperation here before. I am just
> looking for any methodologies for seperation of these tests in
> regards to packaging, and running them etc. I run my tests from
> maven and it would be good to run the two sets of tests seprately
> from each other.
>
I have separate source trees and build output folders for categories  
of tests. I start with two categories: fast and slow. I put any test  
that runs entirely in memory in the "fast" bucket and the rest in the  
"slow" bucket. I run all the fast tests on each important edit and all  
the tests (fast and slow) at least every 15-30 minutes and, of course,  
before committing a change.

Over time, I want to replace tests in the "slow" bucket with tests in  
the "fast" bucket and hand the "slow" tests off to whoever does system  
testing.

I like to keep it that simple. Some find it necessary to have multiple  
categories of "slow" tests, but I strongly doubt anyone who wants  
multiple categories of "fast" tests. Fast tests run at least 200 per  
second. A slow test run would be 2000 tests in 10 seconds. If you have  
that many fast tests, you probably have too big a project or too much  
duplication in the tests. Introduce libraries with their own build  
schedule and refactor your code to get back under 2000 fast tests.

Take care.
